body:
On OS X the first time an application opens it is suppose to be opened in the center believe it or not. On Windows however, the default behavior is whatever looks best according to other Windows on screen. HOWEVER... On OS X a window is not always suppose to be opened in the center every time a program is opened, instead the program should remember the last position of the Window and open it from its last location. NSWindow(s) remember their locations by retrieving a system PLIST file that has its appropriate window name. An appropriate NSWindow name is set and auto-saved in OS X by calling:
```objc
- (void) setWindowFrameAutosaveName: (NSString *);
```
However it is important to note that the method above takes in an NSString which means the problem with doing this in GLFW is that Elimindreda would need to create a way for us to "name" our Windows in our program so that OS X could keep track of their locations. 

Another important thing to note is that after a Window opens, all subsequent windows opened should either default to their last saved location, or they should cascade downward about 20 pixels or so, this behavior is achieved by the following code:
```objc
static NSPoint cascadeLoc = {0, 0};
cascadeLoc = [window->ns.object cascadeTopLeftFromPoint:cascadeLoc];
```
I'm all for this change, however it'd be some work to refactor the code to support window naming, and this new cascade system. If this were to be worked on, it'd be appropriate to give NSWindows their own NSWindowViewController as well.

@jaredjones Thank you for that summary.

I'm not sure whether GLFW should be writing Plists. It'd be the first case of GLFW touching the disk, even indirectly. I won't be able to give this proper attention until 3.0.4 is out and 3.1 starts, however.
It occurs to me that windows are already named, i.e. they have a window title. How useful would it be to you to have this feature implemented using that name?
That would work for me. That might even be OK as default behavior for GLFW windows on OS X? Where are these Plists stored?
I would assume it's under `~/Library/Preferences`, but I will look into it.

That's correct, Apple will write these changes to the DEFAULTS database for that application. The system stores each user's preferences set in a .plist file for each program stored at ~/Library/Preferences for user-specific preferences, and /Library/Preferences/ for global preferences.
I have no time for this in 3.1.
It's not GLFW's responsibility to write files to disk anyway. The user's app can do that if they want to.

It would write to the OS X Cache. Not a big deal at all for GLFW to write a plist to disk as this is standard convention for Window Management on OS X.
Saying that it's not GLFW's job as a window manager on OS X not to create the NSWindow plist doesn't make sense.

That's okay then.

**Edit:** But how would GLFW know the application name? How would it identify this window position vs. another app's window position?
The GLFWCreateWindow takes in a Window Title as a string.
So it's by window title? I suppose there's not much harm in collisions.
I do intend to implement this, although it may not be enabled by default.
